text: CAPTION: Belfast, the Fifties A beautiful ordered garden. The colours are fairy-tale bright. Bird song. On a window an election poster has been taped: VOTE HOOLE

On the grass sits a portable record player. Beside it a small pile of records. CHILD TERRI’S hands pick up ‘I Saw the Light’ - Hank Williams in his trademark rhinestone su - and places it on the turntable A needle is set down on the vinyl. CHILD TERRI smiles, enraptured. A tomato bursts against the window, obliterating the poster. CHILD TERRI dives for cover behind a large shrub. An egg follows the tomato; stones land in the garden alon with arrows from a kid’s bow. The TWO BOYS doing the throwing and shooting are under ten. BOY 1 wears a tatty sheriff's hat, BOY 2 has ‘war paint’ on his face.
Fenian Lovers. An arrow flies overhead. In the shrub CHILD TERRI crouche holding on to his head: he knows he has to keep it down. BOY 2 prepares to unleash a final arrow.
Commie bastards. The shrub seems to vibrate with rage. CHILD TERRI pops up

My da’s not a communist, he’s a socialist. His eye widens as the arrow speeds towards it. Impact. INT. TERRI’S WORLD - NIGHT AND DAY JUMBLED TOGETHER The music is distorted, becoming the soundtrack as the arrow takes us on an accelerated journey into Terri’s world, and through the future, private and public.

Do you think is he going to lose it? There are looming faces - DOCTOR, Terri’s parents MAVIS a GEORGE - a disorienting rush of lights - suggestive of ey tests, but merging with other lights - city lights, searchlights. There are eye charts, which merge with 60s protest placards - US out of Vietnam - Ban the Bomb - wit magazine covers: Ego, OZ MAVIS (CONT’D) Is he going to lose it? The charts, placards, magazines merge with newspaper headlines charting the start of the Northern Irish Troubles, a barrage of surreal images from the 50s to the 70s darker as the headlines change: from agricultural sho to sheep fleeing a bomb blast, from schoolkids dancing at fete to a line of monks being frisked by British soldiers MAVIS (0.S.) (CONT’D) (growing frantic) Is he going to be blinded? Image and sound reach a crescendo.
(consoling) He’s just going to see things a little bit differently.

An explosion fills the TV screen. TERRI, now in his 20s, rubs his eye. There is, throughout an open, almost child-like quality to his expression totally at odds with some of what he does, and says. Beside him sit MAVIS and GEORGE, a man whose bearing, as much as his waistcoat and collarless shirt, marks him as out of his time.
What a fucking nightmare.
Mind you your language.
And they call this a revolution? A poster is on the wall VOTE HOOLEY STILL A GENUINE

TERRI wears a Kodak overall. Sitting on a work bench, kne up, smoking a joint is his mate ERIC - more sixth Stone than fifth Beatle, more Sticky Finger than Satisfaction. There are photos pegged up to dry. There are also flyers (clearly home-made): Terri Hooley, Tonight at 8... Max Romeo’s ‘War ina Babylon’ plays on a portable turntable. TERRI sings along as he pegs up another flyer.
‘War ina Babylon, tribal war ina Babylon, let me tell you, it sipple out there...’
Sssh.
What?
Do you hear something? The ‘something’ is an alarm going off, but it barely registers before TERRI starts singing again.

‘,.. tribal was ina Babylon...’ (breaking off) What baffles me, Jamaica and Belfast have so much in common. Cops and soldiers giving you grief day in day out, armed gangs running round murdering people for fuck all. But at least in Jamaica they have decent music. A muffled thump. TERRI and ERIC look at the door. ERIC nicks the joint; waves smoke away. TERRI opens door and i face to face with a BOMB DISPOSAL MAN, or bomb disposal blimp as he appears.
(indistinctly) Get the fuck out! ERIC jumps down from the bench. TERRI carefully takes the record off before leaving. A second later he returns, gra a handful of flyers.
SOLDIERS herd OTHER WORKERS behind a cordon where news cameras lurk. TERRI and ERIC saunter out
So are you coming down tonight?
You know me, I’ll go anywhere where there are people, ergo....
Jesus, everyone's a defeatist.
Here, just to cheer you up. He passes TERRI a bag of grass.
Tell you the truth, I’m a bit skint at the minute.
(brushing it off) Mates rates. TERRI spies TWO WOMEN IN KODAK OVERALLS; ERIC spies a YOU BRITISH SOLDIER standing a little apart from the others
Catch you later. They go off in opposite directions, TERRI to the women.
The future Mrs Hooley.
Which one of us?
Either of you, both He hands them a flyer.
Come down to this tonight.
In town? Have you a death wish? She and her friend walk off giggling.
(after them, arms spread) I have a life wish. He turns. MARTY heavy beard, heavy coat, heavy politics, approaches, red-headed NED skulking in his wake.
Marty. Ned.
I’d watch where I shouted that life-wish stuff. Some people might take it as a challenge.
(nods to Kodak building) Some people look like they have enough to keep them busy.
That’s not one of ours. If it had been one of ours there wouldn’t have been a warning. He flicks the CND badge on TERRI’s coat. MARTY (CONT’D) I’d forgotten about those.
No kidding.

Does it not get lonely being the last man standing? MARTY glances up, sees ERIC passing something to YOUNG BRITISH SOLDIER, who slips him a banknote in exchange. TERRI sees MARTY seeing it. He flourishes a flyer an inch from MARTY’s face.
Do your feet a favour, take them out dancing, like you used to. MARTY balls up the flyer, shoves it back in TERRI’s face.
See you around. He and NED move off. TERRI has contrived to stick flyers their back.
(under his breath) I fucking hope not.

Deserted, but for TERRI, walking. He stops at length befo a metal cage protecting the front of a bar: the Harp.  6. A security camera tracks his approach. TERRI takes out hi glass eye and thrusts it up to the lens. A buzzer sounds.

The hand that held up the eye now rifles through a box of records: Shangri-las, 13th Floor Elevators, Gladiators. A poster on the wall reads TERRI HOOLEY BELFAST’S NO.1 DJ. Next to it a WAR IS OVER poster (‘Love John and Yoko’), another for the Rolling Stones gig at the Ulster Hall, 19 an outlaws gallery: Hank Williams, Bob Marley, Johnny Cas TERRI downs a brandy, lights a cigarette lit, takes a record from its sleeve: ‘Soul Rebel’ by The Wailers. He places it on the turntable, closes his eyes and starts to sing along.

I'm a rebel, soul rebel He opens his eyes. He is brought back to earth. The room empty save for PAT, the Harp’s Manager (he has one of tho Belfast expressions of permanent doubt: Two plus two? Is four?) and an OLD BOY at the bar doing Spot the Ball. PAT shakes his head slowly, approaches TERRI.
(handing TERRI £5) Here.
I thought we said ten?
Ten for the whole night. That’s you finished, I’m pulling the plug. In fact you needn’t bother coming back.
Why?
Why? Look around you. It’s finished. No one wants to come out any more.

She does. A young woman has appeared out of nowhere and is dancing hypnotically alone in the centre of the floor.  This is RUTH. There is something handmade about her; a style so individual it borders on the eccentric. PAT hands TERRI another £5.

RUTH orders a drink. A loud scratch as, mid-song, TERRI changes tack. Dion, ‘Born to be with you’. The OLD BOY looks round, confused. TERRI skips down from the stage. RUTH is putting change in her purse.
Are you here on your own?
I was out for a walk and heard the music. Thought I’d come in and see if it was as lively as it sounded. The OLD BOY sneezes. TERRI and RUTH look at him, then at each other, then laugh.
It wasn’t always like this, there were nights here when you had to queue just to get on the guest list.
I don’t mean to be cheeky, but you don’t look like a man with that many friends.
Do you want to know the truth of it? I used to have lots of friends.

TERRI and RUTH are surrounded by the very FRIENDS Terri i invoking: swaying to music, laughing, animated. In the middle of the floor three men clink shorts glasses: MARTY less heavy (and wearing a CND badge); NED, and ANDY, with Zapata moustache.

Lots of anarchist friends, and Marxist friends, and socialist friends, and pacifist friends, and feminist friends, and friends who were fuck all.  10 MARTY, NED and ANDY down their drinks. NED’s comes back u his nose. The others laugh, pat his back. NED is furious.
Then the first shot was fired The three shorts glasses smash.

And the first bomb exploded and suddenly I didn’t have any more Marxist, or feminist, or anarchist friends. The room darkens. The FRIENDS are now on opposing sides o the room, MARTY and NED on one side side, ANDY on the other. There is finger-pointing, rancour.
I just had Catholic friends and Protestant friends. And I don’t consider myself either. So...
10 Back to the 70s. The room is empty again save for TERRI a RUTH, the PAT and the OLD BOY.
So now nobody likes you?
Now I’m just a bit more choosy about my friends. Anyway, you’re one to talk, where’s your gang?
They don’t like dancing as much as I do. TERRI reaches over behind the bar for a note pad.
Have you a pen?
I’m an English student, it’s compulsory.
Here, stick your name at the top. RUTH hesitates, shrugs, writes.
(squinting at the page) Are you Martian?  11 12 13 14
Stop it. It’s Ruth. R-U-T-H
Well, R-U-T-H, congratulations, you're the first name on my new guest list.
RUTH pushes TERRI up against the wire grille over a shop window bearing the sign CLOSING DOWN: EVERYTHING MUST GO.
(up for air) Do you want to go back to my mum and dad’s?
No. Do you want to go back to my mum and dad’s?
No.

RUTH is practically trailing TERRI by the hand. INT. DAVE AND MARILYN’S HOUSE - NIGHT 13 An ancient species of Mimeograph machine sits on a table. MARILYN HYNDMAN - a few years older than Ruth - leans against the wall, smoking, while DAVE HYNDMAN circles it, wrench in his hand, trying to decide which bit to hit. RUTH drags TERRI through, tossing out perfunctory introductions
Dave, Marilyn: Terri. Terri: Dave, Marilyn.
The yard has room only for a bin, a bicycle, TERRI and RUTH.
I was at a party here one night, it was all getting a bit much, so I came out here and hid.  15 10.
Where? He follows the line of RUTH’s gaze: the bin.
You’re not serious. He walks over, lifts the lid, looks inside, then turns to RUTH.
Shall we? Hand in hand they each put one leg over then the other, disappearing as though in a variety show magic act. One hand reappears and replaces the bin lid. A pause.
I’ve got a glass eye.
So shut it.
Remind me to tell you my John Lennon story some time.
Shut it.

A wedding picture on the hall wall: Terri and Ruth. Bags and boxes the length of the hallway. TERRI and RUTH are moving in. DAVE comes in through the front door carrying a large carton. TERRI, behind him, carries an ashtray, into which every so often as he rants he flicks ash.
I tell you another thing I hate, that word communities. Whenever anybody in Northern Ireland says community what they’re really saying is side
(from behind the box) You're dead right, it’s false consciousness.  11.
Whereas collective....
«+. people of all religions and none working to a common end...

Mind your feet there, Dave. TERRI bends to set his ashtray on the floor. When he stan ERIC has appeared in the front doorway, looking self- conscious, as well he might under a white cowboy hat. TER does an exaggerated double take.
Don't tell me, it’s Hank Williams's birthday? Roy Rogers’? Desperate Dan’s? ERIC is unable to get a word in before RUTH passes.
Nice hat, Eric. ERIC gives up. MARILYN comes into the hallway. She stops a pile of boxes and reads what’s written on the side.
Terri, Terri, Terri, Terri... (bends to see last one) Terri. She looks around, sees TERRI.
Are these all your clothes?
(points to a black bag on the floor) These are my clothes. (points to the boxes) These are my records.
(lifts a box) Where do you want them?
Back bedroom for now. TERRI stands on the doorstep and lights another cigarette ERIC joins him.  12.
A For Sale sign is now marked Sold.
Listen, I came to tell you, I’m clearing off to London for a while.
Don’t take it so hard, you’re still special. Eric tries to raise a smile without success. He looks ove his shoulder.

I got lifted the other night. The scene behind ERIC darkens. He isn’t standing on the doorstep any more, but on a stool, naked and shivering, h hands covering his groin. HOODED MEN stand around him. ERIC, however, continues to talk as though to TERRI.
A couple of our old anti-war pals were there.
That fucker Marty?
The other crowd. ANDY whips off his mask with one hand, to reveal a leaner infinitely meaner-looking version of his 60s self; with t other hand he brandishes a pair of sheep shears.

Except of course they’re all a bit more pro-war these days. The other HOODED MEN hold shears too now. They advance on ERIC. TERRI winces as the shears flash and snap. One by one the HOODED MEN step back; ANDY is last to go. ERIC is on the doorstep once more. His hand shakes as he takes off the hat. His hair has bee savaged.
Fuck me.  17 18 13.
Told me I was lucky it wasn't a bullet.
For what, dealing a bit of blow? ERIC leans in and takes hold of TERRI’S wrist.

It’s not the drugs. It’s me, it’s you - they try to pass themselves off as the school rebels, we show them up as the prefects. He puts the hat back on so that RUTH coming downstairs doesn’t see his hair. He smiles at her, then at TERRI.
(in an undertone) They want us off the streets. TERRI watches him go.
TERRI sits on the sofa, with an Exchange and Mart open at the ‘Records’ page, a couple of ads circled. RUTH lies across his lap. TERRI sets down paper.
You are everything to me. RUTH laughs, taken aback by the suddenness of it all.
I'll settle for being the most important. MARILYN comes into the room carrying a box.
Don’t mind me working here.
(into RUTH’s hair) Everything.

TERRI walks away from Sorting Office opening a package: records. He walks on past boarded-up shops. A car appears on the far side of the street, traveling in the opposite direction.  19 20 14. TERRI pulls his chin down into his collar as it passes hi The sound of the car fades into the distance, leaving onl TERRI’s footsteps. Another car appears, moving slower, faces at the windows. TERRI retreats further into his collar. When the car has travelled a few yards beyond him it does a U-turn and before TERRI has time to run pulls up at the kerbside. A THUG jumps out. He pulls TERRI’s coat over his head and drags him towards the car. TERRI resists. At one stage his head is inside the car. He and the drive redheaded NED, are eye to eye.
Ned?

(lifting a wheel brace) Here, hit him a whack with this. TERRI in his panic flails, catching NED’s cheek with the record bag. He manages to break free, leaving his coat, sweater, and shirt in the hands of the THUG. Somehow he’s managed to hold on to the bag. He runs. THUG gets out and starts to give chase. Headlights appear further up the street.
Quick, get in. (holding a hand to his face) You’re a dead man, Hooley!
TERRI, topless, stands back pressed against the wall, breathing heavily.
TERRI, RUTH’s dressing gown over his bare torso, is throwing brandy into him, pacing the floor. Terror has given way to anger. RUTH is trying to get him to sit down
Wait, wait, you say you knew this fella?

From the Sixties. He was a prick then and he’s a prick now, only now he’s a prick with a gun.  21 22 23 15. He sits finally, lights a cigarette and closes his eyes. RUTH sits on the arm of the chair beside him. Her gaze roams over his face.
Do you think maybe it’s time we got out of here?

No, that’s what they expect - that’s what they want. He jumps up, knocking over the bag of records. They spill across the floor. He and RUTH start to pick them up. TERRI stops, straightens. RUTH looks at him.
Terri?
Say that again.
I want to open a record shop.
On Great Victoria Street? TERRI nods. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) ‘Bomb Alley’?
A down-at-heel three-storey building in a late-Victorian terrace. TERRI and RUTH, DAVE and MARILYN look up at the frontage.
You’1l have to use a bit of imagination. They go in.
It’s a wreck. There’s a dead pigeon on the floor.
(climbing the stairs) So, whole-food shop down here. (MORE )
People’s printing press on the top floor. They have arrived on the first floor landing.
And you here in the middle.
Do you know how long it’s been since I’ve had someone in here telling me he wanted to open something. He thinks. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) I don’t suppose you have any collateral?
Collateral?
TERRI, DAVE and RUTH walking at (TERRI’s) speed.
I wouldn’t get my hopes up.
They got the Nobel Prize, Dave. A million pounds to promote peace and love! I and I is bringing reggae to the people of Belfast. They have stopped before a sign: PEACE PEOPLE.
Good luck. TERRI hugs her; hugs Dave too.
One love. TERRI and DAVE go in. RUTH watches the door. Nothing happens; nothing happens; nothing happens. Then TERRI com out, DAVE follows.
Fucking hippies.  26 27 17.
I don’t think the John Lennon story helped. TERRI and DAVE walk off. RUTH stands looking after them.
TERRI and RUTH face one another across the table. He is brooding. She reaches under the table for her bag. She takes out an ID card.
What’s that?
I got a job. TERRI picks the card up and reads it.
Truant officer?
Don’t say anything. She takes money from her purse and counts it out on the table: ten, twenty, thirty...
The only thing that has changed is the BANK MANAGER’s tie TERRI is counting out the banknotes RUTH counted out for him: ten, twenty, thirty, and one note more.
(picks up the notes) Forty pounds? He is tempted. He is also a bank manager. A moment. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) You haven't anything a bit more... substantial? TERRI hesitates.
You mean like a house? BANK MANAGER’s face brightens.  28 29 30 18.

(draws on his cigarette) No, it was all pretty straightforward. The forty quid swung it. (runs a finger round the phone’s change drawer) But, here, I might be home a bit late, I just have to go and do something about the, ah, sewers. TERRI pulls scraps of paper from his pocket; dials the number written on one particularly dog-eared scrap. A pause. A deep drag.
Marty? Terri Hooley.
TERRI walks up to a stall on which, among the other crap, are two big boxes of records ‘Pick of the Pops’ to the fo of one. He signals to STALL-HOLDER
I‘ll give you a fiver for the whole lot.

TERRI enters, the very incarnation of Johnny Guitar Watson’s ‘Gangster of Love’, a box under each arm. MARTY is there with a group of REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES (the FRIENDS from the 1968 Harp Bar), among them NED, bruising still around his eye. They watch TERRI stop before their table. He looks over h shoulder. ANDY enters with other LOYALIST PARAMILITARIES (more of the FRIENDS). The REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES instinctively rise from their seats hands going towards their jackets.
Why doesn’t everybody sit down? Both groups do, a wary distance apart. TERRI occupies the space between them.
You know the old saying about the devil and the long spoon?  31 32 19. Everyone is looking at him, wondering where this is going
I thought for a bunch of cunts like you a few LPs would probably do the trick. He fashions a smile, empties a box on one table, a box on the other and spreads the records out: jumble sale crap.
Don’t all dive at once. A moment. They all dive at once.
The tables are closer together. REPUBLICAN PARAMILITARIES and LOYALIST PARAMILITARIES are looking at their albums.
Wait, I already have Desperado. TERRI takes it back, gives him Leo Sayer’s Endless Flight passes Desperado to the Loyalist side.
Right, everybody happy? Nods, murmurs: they’re happy.

OK, now, can I ask you something in return? See when this shop opens, there’s to be no coming round looking a “donation” for the Republican Prisoners... (looks left) «+. or the Loyal Orange Widows... (looks right) And one other thing, there’s to be no trying to kill me. Anybody. Silence.
Now what about one for the road?
TERRI stands at the door, smoking. ANDY comes to stand beside him.
That was some performance you put on there.  33 20.
I try my best.

See those ones in there, though? They’re not the ones you have to worry about. Even the crazies remember the times before this all started. It’s the ones coming up behind them you’re going to have to watch out for. He nods across the street to where a couple of young skinheads wait: MUTT and HATCHET (who has a distinctive spiderweb tattoo on his neck).
It’ll take more than a few LPs to buy them off.
You underestimate my record collection. ANDY pats TERRI’s cheek, without affection. He crosses th street. MUTT and HATCHET fall in behind him.

A life-sized hardboard Elvis comes out the door. TERRI is behind, carrying it. He sets it on the footpath. The word Good Vibrations are painted in red below Elvis’s knees. H left index finger points the way back up the stairs. There is a lame pop. Cheers. The BOD from the Wholefood shop dispenses Elderflower Champagne to DAVE, MARILYN, RUTH, and TERRI. (TERRI slips flask from his pocket and tops up his own ‘champagne’ wit brandy.) A little sea of celebration in the middle of Bom Alley’s wrecked shop fronts and steel shutters A guy with wild hair and greying beard comes down the street: PUGWASH. He stops and looks.
You actually open?
Yeah, we’re open. PUGWASH raises his arms as though to be searched. TERRI hugs him.  34 35 21.
Night is falling. The street is deserted, the buildings i darkness. There is only one figure in the street: Elvis. There is only one light on: Good Vibrations’s.

A hand (TERRI’s) flicks a light switch; presses a button open a cash register; pours coins into the drawers; flips open a receipt book. Finally the hand removes a record fr a sleeve: the Wailers’ Catch a Fire. Sets it on the turntable; lowers the needle. The music swells; TERRI is at the counter, the Outlaws gallery from the Harp on the wall behind him; he looks up There are all of two customers, PUGWASH and A.N.OTHER A.N.OTHER lifts an album.
(shouts ) Great choice, Too Many Saviours on my Cross! A.N.OTHER sets it down and leaves.
It'd be wasted on him.
You're probably right. TWO RUC MEN enter.
(under his breath) Here we go.
See business is going well.
Early days.
(picks up Wailers sleeve: Marley toking) Your old chum Eric has left a bit of a gap in the market and we have our suspicions about who's filled it.
What the fuck are you talking about? It’s a record shop!  36 37 38 22.

So you say. But see if we so much as find two cigarette papers in the same room, it’1ll be an ex- record shop. He sets down the sleeve on his way out. SECOND RUC MAN follows; FIRST RUC MAN turns at the door. FIRST RUC MAN (CONT’D) By the way, is your man out the front anything to do with you? TERRI walks to the window getting there just as the track ends. GEORGE is out on Great Victoria Street, pointing th same way as Elvis.
Don’t let the name fool you. Good Vibrations? Naked capitalism is what it is!
Fuck sake, dad.
It’s the end of the day. Elvis is entering the building, TERRI, as previously, behind.
TERRI counts the takings. He lifts the cash drawer to see if he’s missed any. He hasn't. He looks around the empty shop.
TERRI locks up. He lights a cigarette. He hears youthful laughter. His head turns, looks up an alley, at the same moment as RUTH appears behind him
Boo. TERRI drops the cigarette down his jumper.

I thought I’d walk you home. TERRI has one hand down his jumper the other hand up. The up hand retrieves the cigarette, the down hand beats his chest.  23. A TV CREW has set up on the footpath. An earnest journali - DES - delivers a piece to camera.
For the people of Belfast the nightmare continues. TERRI and RUTH walk through his shot without interrupting their conversation.
How was it today?
Another few customers wouldn’t hurt. One or two under thirty wouldn’t hurt either. What about you?
I haven’t spoken to anyone over the age of twelve.
Another day in the shop. TERRI looks glum. PUGWASH steps up to the counter with a Shangri-las album.
Just the one today, Terri.

Ah, Pugwash, beehives and teenage suicide... we obviously share the same taste in women. Three pound. PUGWASH goes. Behind him stands an odd-looking urchin. Th is FANGS, a Belfast punk, missing a few front teeth.
Have you ‘Orgasm Addict’?
I think you’re in the wrong shop.
Buzzcocks?
Definitely in the wrong shop.
Fuck Off?
What?  24.
If you don’t want to fuck me fuck off, the Electric Chairs? TERRI shakes his head. FANGS looks around.
I thought this was supposed to be a record shop. They stare at one another. TERRI recognises something in the kid’s attitude. He gets a pen, a piece of paper.
I’1l order them. DAVE enters carrying posters, which he gives to FANGS
Here you go, hot off the press. FANGS instantly hands one to TERRI.
(not asking, telling) Stick that up for us. TERRI unrolls it: JANUARY 12TH - RUDI AND THE OUTCASTS - THE POUND, TOWNHALL STREET.
A gig? Who’s putting that on?
Us. TERRI looks at the poster again. When he looks up FANGS i already heading for the door.
Here, where are you hearing all that stuff you were asking me for?
Peel.
John Peel? Last time I heard he was playing Pink Floyd. He turns to the wall, looking for a space. When he can’t see one he takes down the Rolling Stones Ulster Hall bill
Sorry, boys.  40 4l 42 25.
TERRI and DAVE and their echoing footsteps are walking aw from the city centre. Sound of an army helicopter overhea
If I’d known you were going to drag me down here I’d never have printed that thing. He glances anxiously over his shoulder then has to quick- step to catch up with TERRI
You know they used the Pound as a morgue on Bloody Friday.
Fuck sake, Dave. They pass in front of the Albert Clock, round a corner, round another, and there is the Pound, a once-fine bar no barely standing.
There'll be nobody here.

There are people all right. Young people. PUNKS. It’s another city, another world entirely. The journey from the door to the bar is a crash course in teen vice, 1978 vintage: gropings, playful headbuttings, surreptitious glue-sniffing. TERRI and DAVE squeeze in at the bar. DAVE takes out a pound note, conspicuous amid the PUNKS counting out their coins so of course the BARMAN makes straight for him. The PUNKS glare. TERRI turns to look into the room. On a stage lit by a single fluorescent bulb, four crop- haired teenagers are wrenching out a song (basic even for punk) from their instruments. These are the OUTCASTS. Lead singer GREG COWAN exercises his snarl. Guitarist GETTY, shirt off, concentrates so hard on his guitar, he doesn’t notice the girls concentrating on him. Suddenly a number of RUC MEN come in and start nabbing anyone who looks underage (and plenty do), taking names, asking for pockets to be turned out.  26. TERRI pushes his way through the crowd and buttonholes an RUC MAN, writing down the name of a pink-haired PUNK GIRL
Excuse me, officer, I’d like to report a civil war outside. RUC MAN turns. It’s the man who warned TERRI in the shop.
Not you again.
Step back, Hooley.
No, really, take your time. The bombing, shooting, intimidation, that can all wait while you smell her breath to see if she’s been drinking.

(to PUNK GIRL) Stay you there. (to TERRI) And, you, I’ve warned you once: step back. TERRI steps forward. FIRST RUC MAN’s hand moves towards t gun at his hip. Suddenly a single guitar chord sounds. Another band has taken the stage. What they lack in snarl they make up for in cheek. This is RUDI. Down on the floor TERRI and RUC MAN are still squaring up RUDI’s singer RONNIE MATTHEWS leans into the mike.

(more spoken than sung) We hate the cops. TERRI and RUC MAN finally look at the stage where RUDI ar ripping into ‘Cops’. The audience have forgotten about th actual RUC MEN among them and are singing along.

We hate the cops, we hate the cops. TERRI joins in, right in NEAREST COP’s face. The atmosphe has changed, the RUC have lost control. By the door of the bar an RUC SERGEANT gives the signal t withdraw. RUC MAN reluctantly backs off TERRI who is givi it all he has got.  43 27.
When the last cop has gone there is pandemonium. TERRI is in the thick of it, hugging PUNKS, getting head-butted (accidentally? Maybe not, though he appears not to mind).

OK, now that we’ve cleared the air a bit... this is ‘Big Time’. At guitarist BRIAN YOUNG’s opening riff the crowd surges forward. Suddenly the fluorescent stage-light falls from the ceiling.
